contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=July 2009}} {{taxobox |image = AmericanTurkeyOakLeaves.jpg |image_caption = American Turkey Oak foliage |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Fagaceae]] |genus = ''[[Oak|Quercus]]'' |sectio = ''[[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|Lobatae]]'' |species = '''''Q. laevis''''' |binomial = ''Quercus laevis'' |binomial_authority = Walter |}} [[File:Turkeyoakmap.png|thumb|Native Range]] '''''Quercus laevis''''', the '''American Turkey Oak''', is a member of the [[red oaks|red oak]] group of [[oak]]s. It is native to the southeastern [[United States]], occurring on the coastal plain from [[Delaware]] south to central [[Florida]], and west to southeast [[Louisiana]]. [[Image:AmericanTurkeyOakTree.jpg|left|thumb|American Turkey Oak trees]] It is a small [[tree]], sometimes [[shrub]]by, typically only {{convert|8|-|10|m}} tall, though occasionally reaching {{convert|18|m}}. The leaves are variable in size, mostly {{convert|10|-|17|cm}} long but occasionally just {{convert|8|cm}} or as much as {{convert|30|cm}} long. They have 3–7 slender lobes, deeply incised between the lobes, each lobe with 1–3 bristle teeth at the tip. The acorns are about {{convert|20|-|25|mm}} long, and, like other red oaks, take 18 months to mature. [[Image:Quercus laevis-1.jpg|thumb|left|A stand of turkey oaks growing on white sand near the banks of the [[Ocmulgee River]] in the state of Georgia]] The American Turkey Oak typically grows on poor, thin, dry, rocky or sandy soils where few other oaks other than Blackjack oak, ''[[Quercus marilandica|Q. marilandica]]'', can thrive. It does not have the beautiful crown form of many oaks, but is nonetheless a valuable tree for growing on infertile, dry, sandy sites. The deeply lobed leaves are also attractive. It commonly form an understory tree in [[Longleaf Pine]] and other [[pine]] stands on sandy knolls in the southeastern United States. In South Africa, this species is commonly known as just '''Turkey Oak''', but this invites confusion with the [[Turkey|Turkish]] and southern [[Europe]]an species ''Quercus cerris'', [[Turkey Oak]]. The name of the American species derives from the resemblance of the leaves to a turkey's foot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfrc.ufl.edu/4h/Turkey_oak/turkeoak.htm |title=Turkey oak (''Quercus laevis'') |work=Florida Forest Trees |publisher=[[University of Florida]] |accessdate=February 8, 2010}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quercus Laevis}} [[Category:Quercus|laevis]] [[Category:Trees of Florida]] [[Category:Trees of North Carolina]]
